Last Christmas of the '80s Telling Retailers There Ain't No Santa Claus
DOC.TEXT: Overextended consumers and a slowing economy could combine like cheap-spiked eggnog to give many retailers a hangover from the last Christmas season of an extravagant decade. From the swank gauntlet of perfume counters at cash-starved Bloomingdale's to the kiddie departments at K mart, retailers this past week were hoping that the most crucial days of the year would not leave them holding vast quantities of unsold merchandise. Storeowners will take awhile to assess the final days before Christmas. Historically they have been the busiest and in many cases have helped merchants finish the year profitably. A few store chains already say they've done well. But the general tone of this shopping season has been troubling, with some big retailers trying to fend off bankruptcy and most struggling to eke out slim sales increases over last year. Similar spirits were haunting other sectors of the economy during the week. The big automakers said they would have to lay off thousands of workers next month because of slow sales. Northeast banks were taking urgent steps to protect themselves from a rapidly weakening real estate market into which they've loaned billions of dollars. The real estate woes even touched off a sudden drop in the stock market on Monday. The pressure on the retailers has been starkly evident on the streets of New York _ in the racks of sale items at B. Altman & Co., the once classy Manhattan department store that is going out of business because parent company L.J. Hooker is in bankruptcy court, overwhelmed by creditor claims. It's been evident in the heavy discounting at Bloomingdale's and other department stores owned by another retailing company bobbing in debts, Campeau Corp., which warned that its stores might default on their loans and might run to bankruptcy court as well. The pressure on Campeau intensified earlier in the week when a leading apparel supplier and two key lenders in the retailing industry curbed business dealings with the company for fear they wouldn't get paid. To a large extent, Campeau's problems are rooted in one of the leading causes of economic growth and consumer spending of the 1980s _ the rapid accumulation of debt. Campeau relied on debt for its $6.6 billion purchase of Bloomingdale's parent, Federated Department Stores, in 1988. Consumers wooed by the enticements of buying with borrowed money nearly doubled the number of credit cards in in the 1980s and racked up a total debt of more than $700 billion. Debt wasn't the only deterrent to hitting the malls this past week. Nature was a co-conspirator in the retailing industry's troubled season, plunging much of the country into record cold that discouraged shoppers from leaving home. Perhaps the largest lump of coal lobbed at a retailer came from New York State's consumer-activist attorney general, Robert Abrams, who sued Sears Roebuck & Co. for what he called its phony policy of low prices. The nation's leading department store chain, which has been struggling in recent months to find the right recipe to compete with aggressive lower-priced rivals like K mart and Wal-Mart stores, said it was shocked by Abrams' accusations of false advertising and would fight to clear its name in court. In other business and economic news this past week: _The Commerce Department said third-quarter economic growth was revised upward to 3 percent from 2.7 percent; a Commerce survey showed businesses plan to increase capital spending next year despite forecasts of a slowdown; and orders for durable goods increased sharply in November. _Eastern Airlines shrank and American Airlines swelled in another repositioning that reflected the consolidation of their industry. American bought Latin American routes and other assets from Eastern's parent Texas Air Corp. for $471 million. _A well-known takeover speculator convicted of stock manipulation was sentenced to three years' probation and a $250,000 fine, the lightest punishment doled out so far in the series of prosecutions stemming from the Ivan Boesky insider trading scandal. Salim B. Lewis, who had pleaded guilty to stock manipulation, was ordered to spend the probation helping drug addicts.
